importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The couple began their relationship in summer 2004, marking the start of their public relationship and eventual marriage.
The start of their relationship coincides with the decline of Britney Spears' initial commercial peak, influencing public perception of their relationship.
Spears filed for divorce in 2006, signaling the beginning of their legal separation and public acrimony.
The divorce was finalized in 2007, concluding their legal union and triggering custody disputes.
A temporary conservatorship was established in 2008 due to public incidents involving Spears, leading to a permanent one later that year.
The conservatorship was lifted in 2021, marking the end of a long period of external control over Spears’ life and finances.
The book is set to be published on this date, marking a major public release of personal claims and allegations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period covers the relationship between Kevin Federline and Britney Spears, including their marriage, public disputes, and the establishment of the conservatorship due to behavioral concerns.
This period represents the duration of the conservatorship over Spears, which raised significant public debate about mental health, autonomy, and parental responsibility.
The present period includes the release of Federline’s memoir, reigniting public discourse on Spears’ mental health and personal accountability.

keyTakeAways: Kevin Federline's memoir, 'You Thought You Knew,' presents allegations of Britney Spears' erratic behavior as a mother and wife, including drug use during pregnancy and incidents involving her sons.
Federline claims Spears exhibited behaviors such as standing silently in the doorway with a knife during nighttime, and that she drank while pregnant and used cocaine while breastfeeding her sons.
The book asserts that Spears saw her life through a victim narrative and was not in a state to manage her own affairs, prompting support for a conservatorship.
Federline describes the conservatorship as a 'lifeline' and expresses concern that the relationship is 'racing toward something irreversible'.
Spears has publicly rejected the book, calling the allegations 'extremely hurtful and exhausting,' and accusing Federline of profiting from her life and using the narrative to sell a book.
The Free Britney movement is dismissed by Federline, who claims he could never fully support it.
Federline states he waited years to write the book to protect his children and that he has worked to build a life independent of Spears financially.
Federline denies claims of being financially dependent on Spears and emphasizes he has been actively working to build a life for himself and his children.
A spokesperson for Spears says she is focused on her sons' well-being and that the book is being used to profit off her post-divorce life, despite the end of child support.

namedEntities.name: Kevin Federline
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former husband of Britney Spears and author of the memoir 'You Thought You Knew'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure providing a personal account of his relationship with Britney Spears, including allegations of erratic behavior, substance abuse, and mental health concerns.

namedEntities.name: Britney Spears
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pop star and former wife of Kevin Federline
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the subject of the allegations made by Federline in his memoir, and has publicly responded with accusations of defamation and exploitation.

namedEntities.name: You Thought You Knew
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Memoir written by Kevin Federline, detailing his experiences with Britney Spears
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This book is central to the article, as it contains controversial claims about Spears' behavior, mental health, and parenting, and is set for release on October 21, 2025.

namedEntities.name: Conservatorship
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legal arrangement under which others control aspects of Spears’ life
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The conservatorship, which lasted from 2008 to 2021, is cited by Federline as a necessary intervention and a 'lifeline' for Spears, who he claims was unable to manage her own affairs.

namedEntities.name: Preston Spears
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Son of Britney Spears and Kevin Federline
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two sons involved in the custody dispute and a key point in allegations of Spears' behavior during breastfeeding and nighttime presence.

namedEntities.name: Jayden Spears
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Son of Britney Spears and Kevin Federline
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The other son involved in custody disputes and referenced in allegations of Spears’ behavior, including nighttime incidents with a knife.

namedEntities.name: Free Britney Movement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Public campaign advocating for Britney Spears' autonomy and rights
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Federline explicitly states he does not support this movement, contrasting his view of Spears’ behavior with that of supporters who advocate for her independence.

namedEntities.name: The Woman in Me
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Spears' book counters Federline’s claims, accusing him of portraying her as out of control and attempting to profit from her life.

namedEntities.name: BBC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: News organization that reported on the memoir before its release
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The BBC provided early coverage of the memoir, helping to generate public interest and media scrutiny around the allegations.

namedEntities.name: Listenin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Listenin is credited with publishing the memoir, which is set to be released on October 21, 2025.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Kevin Federline, former husband of pop star Britney Spears, releases a memoir titled 'You Thought You Knew' alleging that Spears exhibited erratic behavior as a mother and wife, including drug use during pregnancy and disturbing nighttime incidents involving her sons. He claims that Spears viewed her life through a victim narrative and was unable to manage her affairs, supporting the conservatorship as a necessary 'lifeline.' Spears has responded by accusing Federline of attempting to profit from her life and of unfairly portraying her as out of control, while also defending her relationship with her sons. The book, set for release on October 21, 2025, reignites public debate over Spears’ mental health, parenting, and autonomy, with both parties asserting their version of events.
title: What does Kevin Federline's upcoming book say about Britney Spears?
